pros:
-People are doing amazing work at Lesley, especially faculty and staff; this often goes unnoticed 
-There are very valuable people and supportive colleagues working at this university
-Groups of students are relatively small per class, which makes planning, teaching, and grading more manageable
- Student organizing is very active
- The EDIJ (equity, inclusion, diversity, and justice) office organized amazing events and educational opportunities.
- In my experience, it was manageable to negotiate with immediate supervisors to work from home and teach remotely.
cons:
This institution is poorly run as a business; the students were often referred to as "customers" and the faculty was often asked to take on marketing tasks. 

Students, the faculty (adjunct and core), the staff, or the alleged social justice mission of the university are an afterthought; it is performative. 

Faculty voices are not heard; an 84% vote of no confidence was ignored and rejected. The faculty has little to no agency.

Ethnically minoritized groups, and BIPOC are often labeled as "a problem" for speaking up and not being "palatable". Institutional racism was rarely addressed; we were constantly gaslit and talked down.

The service expectations are ridiculously high, this is particularly burdensome for BIPOC, ethnic minorities, and international employees who are asked to serve in capacities that "educate" colleagues on anti-racism. 

Navigating Human Resources was a nightmare. I oftentimes had unresponded questions; they ignored my emails for months until I asked my supervisors to intervene. HR rarely put anything in writing; everything happens via zoom, and there is no follow-up in writing.

Lesley University does not a tenure system, their process is called "rank and promotion." Folks don't get tenured, only longer contracts. 

Unexamined epistemic racism is prevalent. 

Salaries are ridiculously low, especially giventhe Massachussetts cost of living. 

Cultural appropriation and superficial understandings of sacred practices such as yoga, meditation, and mindfulness are predominant across colleges. When this is brought up by the faculty, the upper administration is non-responsive and complicit with these systems as they are.

pros: The students and faculty are passionate about the work they do.   The reason why I teach here is because of these two aspects only.
cons:
There is no teachers union and the administration is horrible.  The higher level employment does not advocate are seem to care for the interests of the faculty and at times the students, even after prodding and reminders. The salary is horrible, well below what is possibly appropriate for Cambridge living.  Doctoral level Faculty earn significantly less then university staff.  
Administrative offices often misplace documents and the counseling center has a waiting list of students who are in desperate need of services. 
Campus safety is not helpful - crime is rampant among the student community - this is not properly taken care of.  
There is not enough faculty to teach courses which are becoming frequently overloaded with incoming students.  Courses that would most benefit from an intimate learning environment often exceed 25 students.  This is not reflective of what is presented in university advertising.

review_title: the students are treasures, but management is rotten from the top down
pros: students do truly community-changing work, and are eager to share their ideas.  staff and faculty genuinely care about students and most of them try to assist students and one another with navigating Lesley's university-wide broken administrative systems.
cons: middle management does no forward planning, and the top levels of leadership have no focus  implementation strategies. management from the top (president and provost) all the way through deans of the colleges and directors of programs is dismissive of ideas for improvement from staff and faculty.  there is no sense that the top leadership has any idea what happens in its own ground game, which hurts the students.

review_title: Revolving door at the top prevents progress anywhere else

review_title: High workload with relatively low salary but rewarding teaching experience with nice colleagues
pros: Virant student community, rewarding teaching experience, nice colleagues, good health insurance, close connection with the community, recognition of community service

pros: The students are amazing. The location of the Brattle Campus is also good (near great food and cool shops in Harvard Square), but hardly anyone works on this campus, and if you do, your office will probably move in year.
cons: Salaries are low across the board, and there are no benefits like flexible schedules, transportation or childcare subsidies, meaningful professional development money, real paid parental leave, etc. Everything is a fight, so the only people who work here have worked here a LONG TIME and they sit back, do nothing, and collect big checks. Because of the high turnover, job creep is outrageous. People leave, their positions are "frozen" or eliminated, and then you get their work assigned to you in the "interim" but gradually it becomes an expectation of your job. When you try to get it added to your job description or get paid for it, HR ignores you or pretends they can't find your job description so all that extra work is yours. If you complain (which is hard because there is no official place to complain, not even HR), you're accused by management of not being a team player, because you won't allow yourself and others to be abused, and you are "whining" or "over-reacting" or "creating drama"--- classic abuse tactics. I hear this year we won't even get a cost of living increase, which is the equivalent of a pay cut. Also, there are three separate campuses and you have to take a shuttle between them (but it doesn't run in the summer). Because people are scattered, there is no sense of unity or communication between schools or campuses. The administration benefits by sowing division and maintaining these silos. Additionally, the university promotes diversity and inclusion, but it is just a marketing ploy. It's really only people with white savior complexes who don't and won't do any work on themselves. They are big on "raising awareness" through reading books and articles about marginalized groups without actually getting to know any of them, because they won't climb down from their white, cisgender academic towers. Lesley just wants to keep the lights on and recruit students. They will invest in them and in buildings, but they won't invest in faculty or staff, so students are just taught by bitter people struggling to survive. You should also know that this University has the worst reputation in the area among academics and others who work in higher education, except for Simmons University, which, ironically, is what Lesley is looking to imitate.  It's basically a slaughterhouse where you go if you can't work for a school that pays well like Tufts, BU, BC, Northeastern, MIT, etc. Even community colleges pay better than Lesley and have better benefits. Whatever you do, don't work here. Even if you think it's merely a transition to something better, temporary, or stepping stone. Don't do it. You will become so burnt out, broken-spirited, jaded, and mentally unhealthy that you will be a different person than when you arrived, a lesser person both at home and in your field, a shadow of your former self. Even if you've only been there a year. I've seen it happen over and over again. You are not the exception. Please don't do this to yourself. I'm only still here because my partner had a severe injury with multiple surgery and rehabilitation,  and we can't handle a lot change right now.
